reviewText:
This is just simpler version of Bridge Constructor. Maps are definitely less challenging. Apparently this game is directed to beginners. But is that good game? Yes and no. It is a good game if you didn't play first Bridge Constructor. But if you did, there is almost nothing new and nothing challenging here.

VERDICT:
If you like puzzle games and haven't played other bridge building games before, this is a game for you. Buy it and enjoy it, you will be surpriced how much fun is in bridge building.
If you completed first Bridge Constructor game, you will find no challenge here. Buy it on sale only if you want to get all achievements in short time.

Like this review? Consider to join Good Games Giveaways & Reviews group and maybe press big sexy Follow this curator" button on our curation page to read more reviews and win free games."
voteText: 22 of 25 people (88%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Bridge Constructor Playground is a little nice game about bridge building. It's not good like Bridge Constructor Medieval, but basically you can make the same innovations. The biggest lack: theres is not really a story. You just hop from island to island to build bridges across rivers or valleys. The variousity of landscapes is also very low.

There are three different goals: 1. build the cheapest bridge, 2. build a bridge that can handle the weight stress test at its best and 3. build a bridge with only allowed materials. Sometimes there is a limit of money or a certain number of elements you can use. Another goal is to make it safe for trucks. Btw forget about the cars. In the end just the trucks count.

So you play each level 2-3 times to fullfill all goals and then you will notice it's always the same. The bridges with less weight stress are always made out of concrete and cable. The cheapest bridges can be wooden but it mustn't be. And for the material bridges mostly steel and wood is allowed both. Yeah it's challenging but otherwise it can be boring.

Altogether playing this game was mediocre fun but it's OK. In the end there is that notorious facebook achievement which obviously doesn't work for everybody on the first try. That's a bit annoying.

reviewText: Compared to bridge constructor, this game can range from extremely easy to somewhat complicated. This game has no max on budget, but to get specfic medals you need to fit under a budget, only use a type of material, or make a bridge that doesn't go over a certain level of stress. Overall pretty fun and worth a couple hours of entertainment.

reviewText: The concept is simple: build a stable bridge that will successfully withhold large quantities of weight. Connecting platforms to balance the weight and avoiding stress is the key solution to completing a level.
voteText: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I think the term 'Playground' in this installment is an indication to the 'difficulty' of it compared to the others in the series.

Unlike the others, this game has no limit when building a bridge which I think is a good feature, as it allows you to pass some of the harder levels, which otherwise will have you frustrated and stuck. The addition of badges in this game are fantastic as it gives you 5 separate goals to complete on each bridge, that you can do individually, giving a bit of replay-ability and problem solving for each bridge.

There is also a tension/weight meter at the top that displays in real time the pressure on your bridge, which I think is a great addition as it can give you better insight on how/what needs improved on your bridge, and by how much.

Overall I think this is a nice addition to the series, albeit it seems quite shorter than the standard Bridge Constructor. If you are a fan of the series I would recommend the purchase or if you are new to it, I would suggest getting the bundle and playing this one first.

reviewText:
Upsides:
- Actual learning value in the area of bridge engineering and understanding of mechanical and physical principles. Even if the physics engine is not flawless and the means are very limited, with the basics it offers it's still a lot of fun. Physics-based puzzles are more interesting than mere logic-based ones. It's more exciting to have that connection to real-life engineering, and it's fun to watch the result play out.
- Lots of freedom. Feels like there's not one single optimum solution. Being given several approaches in which to build a bridge (cheap, sturdy, materials-limited) further increases the range of possible ways to solve the problems.
- A good bit of creative opportunity apart from the challenges given.
- No handholding. It expects you to figure out the advanced building techniques on your own, but gives you scenarios and tasks that subtly nudge you in the right direction. So it's more like the whole game itself is the tutorial.

Downsides:
- Launcher doesn't save the graphics quality level.
- Steam leaderboards advertised, but they seem to be missing.
- Advertises an extensive tutorial. As mentioned above, that's really not the case. It's at best a moderate tutorial. (The fact is OK, the false description is not.)
- One achievement requires you to share a bridge on Facebook. You can manage to get it even if it fails if you keep trying, but this was almost enough for me to not play it.
- Quite a bit of randomness regarding the results involved, sometimes especially between play sessions. That makes it closer to reality I guess.
- Not enough musical variety.
- Only one setting for music on/off, nothing else sound-wise. But, I guess playing one's own music is the best option here.
- Element highlighing not perfect. It removes the one you're pointing at, but sometimes highlights a different one.

On a more personal note: I havent's played the regular Bridge Constructor, but I think I wouldn't like it. This is called Playground" for a good reason. Outside of the context of the challenges that give you medals
date: the element of scarcity (limited building resources and such) is not present in this game
recommended: and I like that a lot. People tend to live what they train/prepare for
voteText: October 1, 2014

reviewText:
I got this free from a Humble Bundle. If I had paid money for this I would be incredibly sad, especially at a $10 price point directly from Steam.

First Impressions This looks like a bad iPad game written in Unity. Probably because it is.

Controls The entire UI is clearly based around a touch screen, with the cursor acting as a glorified finger. You can't adjust sound levels in the game, I had to adjust them in Windows mixer because it screams at you. You can enable/disable the horrible music with a button on the start screen, that is the extent of the options menu. There are only a couple keybindings, and none are really useful except for undo.

Further Play So after beating the Tutorial missions I wanted to try some of the harder ones. Nope, I have to replay the tutorial missions to get 25 badges."

Badges Badges are horrible. It's literally impossible to accomplish all of them in one run
date: and for the two budget-based ones there are one
recommended: maybe two solutions for each. It's infuriating how low the budgets are set
hoursPlayed: you genuinely do have to do it EXACTLY like it wants you to otherwise you go over budget or load.\n\nIf this was a iPad/Android Tablet game it would be subpar. On a computer this is just horrible. And it's a ripoff of Bridge Project
voteText: which is vastly superior."

reviewText:
I received this game as part of a Humble Bundle a while back, finally decided to play it. The graphics are a bit childish, but I think that's the target demographic considering how simple the levels are. I completed the first island with all badges in a little over an hour, I'm going to assume that if I went for it without trying for all the badges it would have taken considerably less time - maybe 30 minutes. There are 4 islands in the game, which look to all be at a relatively similar difficulty so this isn't a difficult or long game to beat.

I recommend it as a quick way to kill time. It's enjoyable for a bit but then the music's repetitiveness starts to eat away at you and you quit to stop hearing the annoying honks and YAY!"s at the end of every crossing.

In any case
date: worth it on a sale or in a bundle
recommended: I wouldn't pay full price for it
hoursPlayed: but it's still not too bad."

reviewText: It's a fun casual bridge builder. It's pretty simplified from the previous bridge builder games, but the challenges are a neat touch. I beat this game (except for finishing off the badges) in a few hours, so it isn't really worth the $10 - pick it up on a good sale. They added a new material, concrete, that allows building indestructable columns vertically from foundation points. It makes it trivial to solve most bridges, but you won't meet any challenges that way.

reviewText:
This is my first bridge constructor type game, so my review is unbiased by any expectations of previous games!

+ I find it to be mostly fun to experiment with different things. Most of the early bridges are very easy to make it safe for trucks.

- Connecting the bridge to the sides can be slightly hit or miss. Even though you can see the connector on screen, you have to scroll a bit further the the side before it lets you connect to it.

I recommend this game for anybody that enjoys puzzles!

reviewText:
Not a bad game, good for wasting a bit of time when you're bored (until you get bored of the game as well). I got it in a special package so I didn't pay the full retail price and I would recommend that if you want to et this game to wait for a sale as well.

It's your typical construction simulator alongside some side challenges within each level. The art is good and the physics is not bad (although maybe could have been a bit more tweeked at times). The steam acheivements are not bad neither and some seem to be funny when you think about it a bit. It is a rather good challenging game though and works well for most ages.

Rating - 6.2/10
